title: exp/inotify: data race on t.Logf()
body:
ThreadSanitizer says:

WARNING: DATA RACE at 0x0000400780f0
Read by goroutine 2:
  testing.(*common).log()
      src/pkg/testing/testing.go:213 +0x91
  testing.(*common).Log()
      src/pkg/testing/testing.go:218 +0x6a
  exp/inotify.TestInotifyEvents()
      src/pkg/exp/inotify/inotify_linux_test.go:76 +0x83c
  testing.tRunner()
      src/pkg/testing/testing.go:279 +0x86
Previous write by goroutine 5:
  growslice1()
      src/pkg/runtime/slice.c:177 +0x4a
  testing.(*common).Logf()
      src/pkg/testing/testing.go:222 +0x7e
  exp/inotify.funcÂ·002()
      src/pkg/exp/inotify/inotify_linux_test.go:54 +0x1a0
Goroutine 2 (running) created at:
  testing.RunTests()
      src/pkg/testing/testing.go:355 +0xaec
  testing.Main()
      src/pkg/testing/testing.go:291 +0xb7
  main.main()
      /tmp/go-build238601187/exp/inotify/_test/_testmain.go:45 +0xc8
  runtime.main()
      src/pkg/runtime/proc.c:250 +0x91
Goroutine 5 (running) created at:
  exp/inotify.TestInotifyEvents()
      src/pkg/exp/inotify/inotify_linux_test.go:60 +0x5a1
  testing.tRunner()
      src/pkg/testing/testing.go:279 +0x86

The test calls t.Logf() from several goroutines. That causes bad data races in the
testing package. Either the test must synchronize calls to t.Logf() or the testing
package support concurrent logging calls.
